title: A history of events in the Cienega Watershed

events.title: Cretaceous events
events.description: Cretaceous experienced warm climate, high sea levels, inland seas, mass extinction
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Paleo-Indian hunters hunted big game in Southern Arizona
events.description: Humans followed big game (megafauna, mammoth, bison, antelope), smaller animals and gathering plants. No Paleo-Indian sites recorded yet but finding these sites may be difficult due to: 1) sites may be deeply buried and occasionally exposed by erosion into old deposits; 2) the material remains are scant and do not include ceramics, house structures, or other features; 3) due to the mobile patterns; 4) material culture was perishable; and 5) sites are ephemeral in nature and the overall site density would have been low given the hunting and gathering patterns. Site potential exist, known mammoth finds.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: End of Ice Age Ecological Transition
events.description: Temperatures cooler than now, less arid; grassland with marshes
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: PaleoIndian Period human settlement continues
events.description: In the Cienega watershed, small groups of humans continued to hunt large animals and game though actual sites are lacking.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Human settlements and activities during the Archaic period became highly adaptive to area landscape.
events.description: The Archaic prehistory period was marked by patterns of hunting and intensive plant collecting with seasonal mobile camps for thousands of years. Many sites exist in the Cienega Valley attesting to this successful adapation to changing environments.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Climatic transition period: warmer and drier than today
events.description: Warmer and drier than now, channel-cutting with erosion periods during the transition.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Temperatures began to drop and activite erosion periods
events.description: Incisions and filling events on Cienega Creek resulting in buried archaeological sites
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Archaic Farmers: Early Farming along Cienega Creek
events.description: Fields, pithouses, small hamlets, villages along Cienega Creek, less mobile; farming on floodpains; some activities revealed in deep buried agricultural sites
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Moisture and Temperatures similar to today create opportunities for new economic activities
events.description: Agriculture increasingly possible in watershed in floodplains and some dry locations.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Widespread farming communities and settled village lifestyle develop
events.description: Large pithouses, courtyards, ceramics, settled life; larger villages, some ballcourts occur
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Climate drying, Hohokam adapt with longer settlement and intensive agriculture
events.description: Some large Hohokam site, public structures; agriculture aided with check dams terraces; long-occupied sites at I/10 and Cienega Creek; plus smaller farming sites
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Proto-historic Apache and Sobiapuri Native Americans living in the watershed
events.description: Sobiapuri communities found at multiple locations including Colossal Cave
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Spanich Contact with Apache or other native groups
events.description: Apache and Sobiapuri living in area where Coronado crossed
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Hohokam and protohistoric use Colossal Cave area
events.description: Colossal Cave used as a shrine by Native Americans
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Dryland farming possible along floodplains, washes and with irrigtion
events.description: Proto-historic, post-Hohokam groups living in smaller communities with diverse economics
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Spansh presence initiated in Native American areas
events.description: Livestock introduced by Jesuit Father Kino
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Temperatures and moisture vary as in today's watershed climate
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Father Kino expores Southern Arizona Pimera Alta
events.description: Jesuit Father Eusebio Francisco Kino expores S. AZ Pimera Alta
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Sobaipuri probably moved west to avoid Apache expansion
events.description: Some groups may have dispersed east as well
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Euroamerican settlement spread during the Spanish Colonial period; Tucson presidio
events.description: Spread of livestock and new plants during Spanish Colonial period
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: US General Land Office established 1812

events.title: Cattle became dominant regional (exotic) ecological force
events.description: Beginning in 1800s and continuing into today,cattle became dominant regional ecological force, an exotic influence on native ecosystems
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: US war with Mexico ending in the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Arizona lands added to the United States

events.title: 1848 Emory boundary survey includes Sonoita Plains
events.description: Emory boundary survey reports on wildlife etcs in region.  Crew gets lost in Sonoita Plains, confused by 3 rivers. Reports  marshes, bogs
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Department of the Interior established
events.description: General Land Office was transferred to the DOI

events.title: Earliest American settlements in the Gadsen Purchase area were in the Sonoita Valley
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: February—the US flag was raised over Tucson
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: 1857-early 1880s  Various stage lines operate across AZ from San Diego, CA to San Antonio, TX
events.description: Civil War provided a 4-year interruption of the stage lines

events.title: Southern Pacific Line operates a stagecoach stop at LaPosta Quemada Ranch.
events.description: According to Edward Vail, by 1875 a burned stage station existed, hence Posta Quemada -Burnt Station. Southern Pacific Line operates a stagecoach stop at what is today part of LaPosta Quemada Ranch. Clossal Cave.

events.description: Beavers lost from Gila River System including Cienega Creek

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad facilitating train  heads east from Tucson for Pantano passing through Vail's Siding.

events.title: December 15, 1880 the Southern Pacific Railroad is connected with the Santa Fe Railroad at Deming, NM. Train eliminates most stage lines including Nat Mail & T Co., ; no need for Mtn Springs as a stage station.
events.description: By April 1880, Southern Pacific Railroad tracks made it to Punta de Agua where the Pantano Wash and Cienega Creek meet along the old wagon rd.  Railroad is constructed as a levee in the broad floodplain of Cienega. Vail's Siding was built on the last stretch of that land before the railroad tracks entered Cienega Creek.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum E L. The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch, Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation, 2000

events.title: Severe drought for 2 years
events.description: Up to 75% of cattle died after nearly all forage had beed decimated;   ecosystem had not co-evolved with this type of grazing intensity
events.source: #Bock, Carl E. & Jane H. Bock. 2000.  View from Bald Hill. University of California Press

events.title: Total Wreck Mine on Empire Ranch
Great Train Robbery that never was gives rise to Bandit Legend
events.description: Colossal Cave.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum E L. The Timeline: The intertwined histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch, Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation, 2000

events.title: 1887 May 3, first of 4 earthquakes or aftershocks; one estimated 7.2 causes banks of San Pedro R to become 15-20 ft deep; later shock Nov 11, cracks wooden depot bldgs in Pantano.
events.description: Tombstone reports significant aftershock on May 30; Breaks up playas, forms Mustang Mts skyline used in Red River film; aftershocks felt from Phoenix to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico and from Yuma to Santa Fe

events.title: Spanish American War
A fine freight road built from Helvetia to Vail's Station.
events.description: This road was needed to transport ore from the mines in and around Helvetia to a point where it could be shipped for processing. Helvetia Mining Company approached the Pima County Board of Supervisors about sharing the cost of the road and bringing the buisiness to Tucson. Inaction on the part of the Supervisors brought the road to Vail's Siding. Mining in the Santa Rita Mountains and the new road were a catalyst for growth in the area.
events.source: Lamb JJ, The Old Vail Post Office.The Smoke Signal.The Tucson Corral of the Westerners, 2011

events.title: James Steson acquires Kentucky Camp mining claims, water rights
events.description: acquires mining claims, water rights and reservoirs for a large scale hydraulic gold mining operation. George McAneny and James Stetson form the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company on October 3rd.
events.source: Orrell FL Kentucky Camp and the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company, Kentucky Camp Chronicles, 1998

events.title: The first federal land survey establish boundaries of San Ignacio del Babacomari Grant.
events.description: The first federal land survey in the Research Ranch area was done in June 1902, to establish boundaries of San Ignacio del Babacomari Grant.

events.title: Antiquities Act passed; still valid and in use
events.description: Antiquities Act preserves prehistoric, historic & scientifically significant sites, creates national monuments;  (Pub.L. 59–209, 34 Stat. 225, 16 U.S.C. § 431–433), signed into law by T Roosevelt June 8, 1906. This law gives the President the authority to, by presidential proclamation, create national monuments from public lands to protect significant natural, cultural or scientific features. The Act has been used over a hundred times since its passage, sometimes  controversial.

events.title: Fire destroys Vail Store & Post Office (Schley's Store). The store is rebuilt and open for business by August 1908
events.description: The origin of the fire was unknown. The store was a the largest of the country stores in the area serving Helvetia camp and other mining camps as well as local ranches and Southern Pacific Railroad workers.
events.source: Lamb JJ, The Old Vail Post Office. The Smoke Signal. The Tucson Corral of the Westerners, 2011

events.title: Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 passed
events.description: Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 30 U.S.C. § 181 et seq. is a federal law that authorizes and governs leasing of public lands for developing deposits of coal, petroleum, natural gas and otherhydrocarbons, in addition to phosphates, sodium, sulfur, and potassium in the US. Previous to the act, these materials were subject to mining claims under the General Mining Act of 1872.

events.title: AZ cotton decision giving all rights to groundwater
events.description: AZ cotton decision, based on legal analysis of hydrology (information from 1912 used in decision) – effect was to essentially give all rights to groundwater, not surface water [no protection in AZ for surface water --- groundwater withdrawal causing impacts now]

events.title: Taylor Grazing Act passed to regulate access for grazing on public lands
events.description: Taylor Grazing Act of 1934 authorized grazing districts and regulations on public lands. (Pub.L. 73–482) (excluding Alaska) to improve rangeland conditions and regulate their use; administered by the Department of the Interior. As amended, the law applies to approximately 162,000,000 ac  inside grazing allotments. These can be vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved land from public lands, all except for Alaska, national forests, parks, monuments, Indian reservations, railroad grant lands, etc.  Permits are given for grazing privileges in the districts.; or to build fences, reservoirs, and other improvements.  Permittees are required to pay a fee; permit cannot exceed ten years but is renewable. Permits can be revoked because of severe drought or other natural disasters that deplete grazing lands..

events.title: Border Patrol begins and eventually expands operations in the Southwest
events.description: The U.S. Border Patrol was founded on May 28, 1924, as an agency of the United States Department of Labor to prevent illegal entries along the Mexico–United States border and theUnited States-Canada border.

events.title: Mexican-American War
events.description: The Mexican–American War, also known as the Mexican War, the U.S.–Mexican War, the Invasion of Mexico, the U.S. Intervention, or the United States War Against Mexico, was an armed conflict between the United States of America and the United Mexican States from 1846 to 1848 in the wake of the 1845 U.S. annexation of Texas, which Mexico considered part of its territory despite the 1836 Texas Revolution.

events.description: The Coronado National Forest Reserve was established in 1908 resulting from combination of several local Forest Reserves in Southeast Arizona and Southwest New Mexico.

events.title: "Transfer Reductions"  Policy
events.description: The management of the Coronado National Forest Reserve began with an emphasis on reducing the stocking rate and a policy of "transfer reductions" requiring a 10% reduction in permitted numbers each time a permit was reissued. The policy was effective and resulted in removal of hundreds of cattle from Coronado. By the early 1950s, many ranges were no longer overstocked and the policy was rescinded (Allen 1989).

events.title: Farm Bill
events.description: In the United States, the farm bill is the primary agricultural and food policy tool of the federal government. The comprehensive omnibus bill is passed every 5 years or so by the United States Congress and deals with both agriculture and all other affairs under the purview of the United States Department of Agriculture. The farm bill was first created during the Great Depression to give financial assistance to farmers who were struggling due to an excess crop supply creating low prices, and also to control and ensure an adequate food supply.[4] The first farm bill, known as the Agriculture Adjustment Act (AAA), was passed by Congress in 1933 as a part of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.[5] The bill allowed farmers to receive payment for not growing food on a percentage of their land as allocated by the United States Secretary of Agriculture. It also enabled the government to buy excess grain from farmers, which could then be sold later if bad weather or other circumstances negatively affected output. The AAA also included a nutrition program, the precursor to food stamps.[6]

events.title: Soil Conservation Service establishes.
events.description: The agency was founded largely through the efforts of Hugh Hammond Bennett, a soil conservation pioneer who had worked for the Department of Agriculture from 1903 to 1952. Bennett's motivation was based on his knowledge of the detrimental effects of soil erosion and the impacts on U.S lands that led to the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. On September 13, 1933, the Soil Erosion Service was formed in the Department of the Interior, with Bennett as chief. The service was transferred to the Department of Agriculture on March 23, 1935, and was shortly thereafter combined with other USDA units to form the Soil Conservation Service by the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1935. Hugh Bennett continued as chief, a position he held until his retirement in 1952. On October 20, 1994, the agency was renamed to the Natural Resources Conservation Service as part of the Federal Crop Insurance Reform and Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994.

events.title: The Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act
WWII
Conservation Needs Inventory
events.description: By the early 1940s, The Soil Conservation Service (SCS) realized natural resources information was required to develop programs and set priorities for various conservation needs throughout the country. After assembling and analyzing the available resources data, SCS published in 1945 a report on U.S. soil and water conservation needs, which became the Conservation Needs Inventory (CNI) and prepared the ground for future inventories.

events.description: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) was established to protect the quality of drinking water in the U.S. This law focuses on all waters actually or potentially designed for drinking use, whether from above ground or underground sources.

events.title: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
events.description: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) gives EPA the authority to control hazardous waste from the "cradle-to-grave." This includes the generation, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous waste. RCRA also set forth a framework for the management of non-hazardous solid wastes. The 1986 amendments to RCRA enabled EPA to address environmental problems that could result from underground tanks storing petroleum and other hazardous substances.

events.title: Food Security Act

Environmental Quality Incentives Program
events.description: The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) provides a steady and major source of annual support since 1997. In 1997, NRCS was authorized to provide $2 million throughout Arizona through EQIP and it was gradually increased to $10 million in 2002 and reached $20 million in 2006. A total of 177.5 million dollars was invested from 1997 through 2012. Most of the EQIP money was spent for water development, drought fund, and planning, implement of conservation practices. It’s a great help to maintain and improve rangeland conditions, especially to alleviate the drought damage brought by the continues warming and drying climate starting the late 1990s.

events.title: Agricaltural Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act
The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan
events.description: The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan (SDCP) is guiding regional efforts to conserve the best lands and most precious resources for future generations of Pima County residents to enjoy. The Plan combines short-term actions with long-range land-use decisions in Pima County, one of the most biologically diverse counties in the U.S. From cactus-studded deserts to conifer forests, the diverse landscape of Pima County is the home to a million residents from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and contains a rich diversity of plant and animal life.

The Arizona surface water code was enacted
events.description: Early in its history, Arizona adopted the doctrine of prior appropriation to govern the use of surface water. This doctrine is based on the tenet of “first in time, first in right” which means that the person who first puts the water to a beneficial use acquires a right that is better than later appropriators of the water.Prior to June 12, 1919, a person could acquire a surface water right simply by applying the water to a beneficial use and posting a notice of the appropriation at the point of diversion. On June 12, 1919, the Arizona surface water code was enacted.  Now known as the Public Water Code, this law provides that a person must apply for and obtain a permit in order to appropriate surface water unless: 1. The water is from the mainstream of the lower Colorado river, in which case a contract with the Secretary of the Interior is required. 2.The person or the person’s predecessor-in-interest, lawfully appropriated the water prior to June 12, 1919 and the person or the person’s predecessor-in-interest has filed a statement of claim for the appropriation with the state. 3.The water is stored in a stockpond constructed after June 12, 1919 and before August 27, 1977.

Environmental Protection Agency estibishes.
events.description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency[2] (EPA or sometimes USEPA) is an agency of the U.S. federal government which was created for the purpose of protecting human health and the environment by writing and enforcing regulations based on laws passed by Congress.[3] The EPA was proposed by President Richard Nixon and began operation on December 2, 1970, after Nixon signed an executive order.

events.title: National Forest Management Act
Colossal Cave Mountain Park Expansion
events.description: Pima County’s first efforts to conserve Colossal Cave began in 1944, when the County leased almost 500 acres from the State Land Department for purposes of a park.  Using 1986 voter-approved bond funds for park land acquisition, the County began to establish the mountain park to protect the cave in 1989 and a Pima County park was formally established in 1992.  Acquisitions included the historic Posta Quemada Ranch, which is also the site of a 120-year old stagecoach station.  Colossal Cave Mountain Park (CCMP) supports habitat for almost half of the bat species in the State of Arizona, including the endangered Lesserlong-nosed bat.  CCMP also protects large segments of lush riparian vegetation along Agua Verde Creek, a major tributary to Cienega Creek.

events.title: Walden and Other Properties that Contribute to the Reserve
events.description: The properties were acquired because of their basic ecological and habitat values. Walden Property McKenzie Property Poteet Property Amadon and Nunez Properties

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Expansion
events.description: Recognizing the incredible importance of Cienega Creek and its watershed, the Board of Supervisors established the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve in 1986 using voter-approved bond funds for floodprone land.  Spanning 4,000 acres, the Preserve protects 12 miles of the lower reaches of Cienega Creek, which supports native endangered fish species, provides aquifer recharge, and provides important natural flood control protections that lessen impacts to the developed areas in the Tucson Basin.  The Preserve also hosts the historic railroad town of Pantano, along with many archaeological features, including bedrock mortars.

events.title: The acquisition of Bar V Ranch
events.description: Pima County’s acquisition of the Bar V Ranch contributes to the conservation of one of the most important wildlife movement corridors in the Cienega Valley.  The 14,400 acre Bar V Ranch is located between the Rincon and Santa Rita Mountains, andadjacent to the County’s Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.  The ranch includes a significant portion of Davison Canyon, an important tributary and water source to Cienega Creek and the Tucson Basin.  Acquisition of the Bar V Ranch preserves a large intact piece of the Empire-Cienega landscape and protects important riparian habitat crucial for several vulnerable species.

events.title: The acquisition of Sands Ranch
events.description: In its entirety, the historic Sands Ranch totals 64,000 acres, spanning east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to the San Pedro River in Cochise County.  With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County acquired the 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch located in the far southeast corner of Pima County.  This acquisition further connects a system of publicly-owned lands from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains, especially when coupled with the County’s subsequent acquisition of the adjacent Clyne Ranch.  Not only does it contribute to the health of the Cienega Watershed, but also conserves high quality native grasslands and wildlife movement corridors.

events.title: The acquisition of Empirita Ranch
events.description: The Empirita (little Empire) Ranch actually broke off from the larger Empire Ranch in 1941. In 1991 and 92, the Pima County Flood Control District purchased 360 acres of the Empirita Ranch. In 2001, Pima County’s acquisition of the 2,700-acre Empirita property conserved the last remaining portions of the private land that comprised the historic Empirita Ranch.  With assistance from the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County negotiated the purchase of the Empirita property, along with the owner assigning the County its contractual right to withdraw up to 1,600 acre feet of groundwater annually from the Cienega Creek Basin.  The Empirita acquisition expands upon already conserved reserves, including the Coronado National Forest, the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, and the County’s Bar V Ranch, Empirita Ranch and Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.

events.title: The acquisition of Clyne Ranch
events.description: The County’s acquisition of 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch,located east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, in December 2008, created an interconnected corridor of conserved lands spanning from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains.  With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County then acquired the Clyne Ranch parcels, located adjacent to the County’s Sands Ranch and also east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, totaling 880 acres.  In addition, development restrictions were placed on 90 acres maintained by the seller. The ranch is an integral part of this assemblage of publicly-owned lands and further contributes to this corridor through the Cienega Valley.  The Clyne Ranch parcels, like the Sands Ranch, contains high quality native grasslands found in the Sonoita Valley area.

events.title: The Civilian Conservation Corps efforts in Southern Arizona.
events.description: The Southwest's first Civilian Conservation Corps constructed hundreds of miles of drift fences and numerous water developments on the Coronado during the 1920s and 1930s.Allotments with relatively light stocking rates showed marked improvement. However, the goal of these water developments and fencing were on increasing range capacity and separating animals.  Yet little attention was given to the basic principles of range management such as improving livestock distribution through fencing or rotational grazing (Allen, 1989).  This resulted in heavy use in new areas and brought significant forage competition with resident wildlife.

events.title: Empire Ranch sold to Chiricahua Ranches Company
events.description: The Chiricahua Ranches Company, owned by Henry, Frank, and Charles Boice, purchases the Empire Ranch.
events.source: History of the Empire Ranch by Gregory Paul Dowell.  Master’s Thesis, University of Arizona, 1978.

events.title: Frank and Mary Boice move to the Empire Ranch.
events.description: Frank and Mary Boice and their young sons Frank (Panch) and Robert (Bob) move to the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: Dry season
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 58. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Widespread drought
events.description: Widespread drought; in June, AZ declared a drought state, S. AZ counties declared “…emergency areas”
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 60. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Taylor Grazing Act passed.
events.description: Taylor Grazing Act; “…the first national law to provide for regulated control of the unappropriated grazing lands…”  The act was intended to help prevent overgrazing and erosion.
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 69. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: WPA project number 274 commissioned to classify all state lands.
events.description: WPA project number 274 commissioned to classify all state lands. The project included a “…physical examination [of the ranch lands]…drafting of a topographical map for each township…the carrying capacity was estimated, rainfall and soil conditions determined…”.
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 73. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Federal soil conservation program begins.
events.description: Marks the beginning of the Federal soil conservation program; this was a partnership between the state of Arizona, the Soil Conservation Service and the Department of Agriculture (Wagoner, 73). The program was designed to help restore the land to its previous carrying capacity.
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 73. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Soil Conservation Range Benefit Program begins.
events.description: Agricultural Adjustment Administration announces the Soil Conservation Range Benefit Program (a range improvement/erosion mitigation/stock distribution program).  “…by the summer of 1937 some 450 Arizona ranchers were co-operating…”
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 61. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Range Conservation Program begins.
events.description: Range Conservation Program begins; it was designed to encourage distributed grazing also, “…water spreading, gully stopping, spring development, and the eradication of cactus, cedar and mesquite”
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 62. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Dry season
events.source: History of the cattle industry in Southern Arizona, 1540-1940 by Jay J. Wagoner, University of Arizona Bulletin.  1952; 23(2): 115. Social Science Bulletin no. 20

events.title: Seasonal droughts
events.source: Conover, A. (2007). Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Heritage Publishers. Pheonix, AZ, 2007:44

events.title: Severely dry.
events.source: Dunklee, J.  Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona. Thesis (M.A.)--University of Arizona, 1967:38 #MBDI Drought Index, 1896-1962

events.title: Drought conditions.
events.source: Dunklee, J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona. Thesis (M.A.)--University of Arizona, 1967:38

events.title: Red River filmed at the Empire Ranch.
events.description: Red River, starring John Wayne, is filmed at the Empire Ranch and other local locations.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: Cloud seeding attempted.
events.description: An attempt at cloud seeding initiated by local ranchers; the program ran from June 15-September 30. Mr. A.C. Barnes of the Precipitation Control Company was hired to do the job, but produced inconclusive results.
events.source: Conover, A. (2007). Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Heritage Publishers. Pheonix, AZ, 2007:39

events.title: Huachuca House installed at the Empire Ranch.
events.description: A remodeled surplus building from the army base at Ft. Huachuca is installed west of the Empire Ranch House as a home for Bob and Miriam Boice.
events.source: Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual, 2015

events.title: Arizona drought disaster declared.
events.source: Conover, A. (2007). Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Heritage Publishers. Pheonix, AZ, 2007:44

events.title: Frank and Mary Boice become sole owners of the Empire Ranch.

events.title: Rooms in the Victorian Addition of the Empire Ranch House remodeled.

events.title: Bob Boice moves to Globe, AZ to manage the Slash S ranch.

events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.description: Frank Seymour Boice dies.  Management of the Empire is taken over by his sons Pancho and Bob.

events.title: Gulf American Corporation purchases the Empire Ranch
events.description: Gulf American Corporation purchases the Empire Ranch.  GAC plans to build a large residential community development.  GAC contracts with Pancho Boice to continue managing the Empire Ranch under lease arrangements.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: Drought was declared in Arizona.

events.title: Frank (Pancho) Boice dies.
events.description: Pancho Boice dies in a plane crash.  His son Steve takes over sole reponsibility for the operations on the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: Anamax Mining Company purchases the Empire Ranch.
events.description: Anamax Mining Company purchases the Empire Ranch from GAC for its water rights and mineral potential.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: John Donaldson leases the Empire Ranch.
events.description: John Donaldson enters into a lease arrangement with Anamax to operate the Empire Ranch.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: Mac and Billie Donaldson partner with John Donaldson.
events.description: John Donaldson's son Mac and his wife Billie move to the Empire Ranch to partner with John.

events.title: Bureau of Land Management acquires Empire Ranch.
events.description: BLM acquires Empire Ranch through a land exchange, administered as Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area.  Donaldson's ranching lease and use of headquarters continues.
events.source: Empire Ranch by Gail Waechter Corkill and Sharon E. Hunt, Charleston, SC, Arcadia Publishing, 2011. Images of America series, p. 46

events.title: Emory boundary survey includes Sonoita Plains
events.description: Emory boundary survey reports on wildlife etc in region.  Crew gets lost in Sonoita Plains, confused by 3 rivers. Reports  marshes, bogs

events.title: Rosemont Mining Claims located in Wash and Barrel Canyons.
events.description: William McCleary and L.J. Rose begin locating Rosemont mining claims near Wasp and Barrel Canyon. Rosemont claims in present day Coronado National Forest.
events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont Narraganett claim located
events.description: Rosemont Narraganett claim: James K. Brown locates the claim and begins intermittent operations.
events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: VR Ranch established in Rosemont Valley,
events.description: Edward Vail starts VR Ranch, associated with the Vails’ Empire Ranch. Located in present day Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: Hidden Valley or Scholefield Ranch established.
events.description: George Scholefield founds the Hidden Valley or Scholefield Ranch. Located in present Coronado National Forest
events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: Martinez and Lopez families known to have ranched in the area.
events.description: Martinez and Lopez families ranching in the area; ranches never patented. Within present day Coronado National Forest.
events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: McCleary and Rose incorprate the Rosemont Smelting and Mining Co.

events.title: McCleary becomes first Post Master of Rosemont PO.

events.title: Rosemont Copper Company begins
events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont: Lewisohn Brothers patent 21 mining and 7 mill claims

events.title: Santa Rita Forest Reserve proclaimed.

events.title: Rosemont: First Ranger cabin built at Old Rosemont

events.title: Economic depression halts Rosemont mining

events.source: Gillespie W.  A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication. September 10, 2008. Revised May 8, 2015.

events.title: Rosemont Administrative Site withdrawn from public entry.

events.title: The Mexican period brings de-centralized political and economic activity on the northern frontier and increased violence on Apaches.
events.description: The Mexican period brings a sharp drop in levels of national (centralized) political and economic activity on the northern frontier; weaker than Spanish national control. Local politics and economy become more important. The northern provinces become more isolated than under Spanish government. Mexican authorities lose control of the northern frontier. Mexicans resort to increased violence when dealing with Apaches. They eventually place bounties on Apaches and hire bounty hunters to bring in Apache scalps. Bounty hunters prey on peaceful rancherias, which are easy targets, more than on hostile Apaches. Some presidios, apparently, poison Apaches. Apaches generally become more hostile and retaliate more frequently against the Mexicans than they did against the Spanish. Revenge  becomes an important driving force of hostilities. The frontier economy declines during these years. Military garrisons decrease in size. Civilian militias become more important, although largely ineffective. Economic support by the central government of the Apaches declines. Mexican communities frequently take hostages to use as advantage against the Apaches. Apaches do the same. Apaches frequently trade goods to one community that they take from another. Political confusion exists on the northern frontier. Mexicans become increasingly worried about a general Apache revolt.
events.source: Rushforth, Scott et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site. Denver, CO:US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office. 2010. p.82

events.description: Chiricahua Apache Reservation established.  First interlude of peace in more than 40 years.Boundaries include San Simon Valley south of Gila River to Mexico border and Dragoon Range to New Mexico border. Reservation cancelled in 1876. Land returned to public domain and Apaches removed to San Carlos reservation. Many renew raiding patterns.
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.title: Fort Lowell (Tucson) moved.
events.description: Fort Lowell moved from Tucson City to northeastern corner of Tucson basin.

events.title: Township around Empire Ranch surveyed.

events.description: Fort Huachuca established.

events.description: Ed Schieffelin makes first discovery of silver ore at Tombstone. Initiates explosion of mineral exploration throughout southern Arizona.

events.description: Completion of SPRR through Arizona opens new national markets to SE AZ ranchers, new shipping opportunities for miners.

events.title: Empire Mining and Development Co operate Total Wreck mine and milling operations
events.description: Major development of Total Wreck mine and milling operations by Empire Mining and Development Co. Mine produces $500,000 of silver ore that supports expansion of cattle and land operations at Empire Ranch. Silver market declines dramatically in 1884.
events.source: Dowell G. History of Empire Ranch. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona.1978. p.48-49

events.title: Walter Vail files on mining and mill sites to acquire water.
events.description: Walter Vail files on numerous mining and mill sites primarily to acquire and secure water sources.
events.source: Dowell G. History of Empire Ranch. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona.1978. p.58

events.title: Walter Vail acquires Happy Valley ranch (Rincons) and Meadow Valley ranch Empire Valley.
events.description: Walter Vail acquires the Happy Valley ranch in eastern Rincons and Don Sanford’s Meadow Valley ranch at northern end of Empire Valley. Acquisition of meadow valley ranch provides water source to run Total Wreck mine milling operations. Both provide major control of grasslands in region.
events.source: Dowell G. History of Empire Ranch. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona.1978. p.58

events.title: Walter Vail expands stock raising business into breeding race horses.
events.description: Walter Vail, like many other large cattle operators, expands stock raising business into breeding race horses.
events.source: Dowell G. History of Empire Ranch. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona.1978. p.67

events.title: Walter Vail and Josiah Voseburg operate Pantano Ranch, Cienega Creek
events.description: Walter Vail partners with Josiah Voseburg to operate 2700 acre Pantano ranch on Cienega Creek
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.title: Final surrender and deportation of Chiricahua Apache.
events.description: Final surrender and deportation of Chiricahua Apache to San Augustine prison in Florida. Southeastern Arizona now released from development restrictions.
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.title: Vails sell Total Wreck mine.
events.description: Vails sell Total Wreck mine.
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.description: Vails defy SPRR and raised shipping prices and conduct last major cattle drive from Arizona to California.
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.title: Forest Reserve Organic Act.
events.description: Allows president to create reservations of land to protect the headwaters of water resources or to control access to timber resources. Act allows holders of patented lands or valid homestead claims to trade acreage for other unclaimed lands from the public domain. Also to sell rights for paper scrip.
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.title: Wlater Vail and Carroll Gates buy 1000 acres of scrip from Sierra Forest reserve lands.
events.description: Vail and partner Carroll Gates buy 1000 (and most likely much more than that) acres of scrip from lands in the Sierra Forest reserve.In 1899 they exchange scrip for over 2000 acres of lands in Empire Valley and other southern valleys. These sites cover many water sources. Dowell: 115. Also general land office land patent records under Walter Vail.
events.source: Pinto R. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication. February 1, 2015.

events.description: Forest reserves renamed National Forests. Whetstone Mountains added to Santa Rita National Forest. Rincon Mountains added to Santa Catalina National Forest.

events.description: Establishment of National Park Service to administer national parks and monuments.

events.description: Tucson Plant Material Center established. for erosion control under Soil Conservation Service. FJ Crider imports Lehmann lovegrass and other nonnative grasses from South Africa for testing for erosion control and range revegetation in SE AZ.
events.source: Crider FJ. Three Introduced Lovegrasses for Soil Conservation. US Department of Agriculture Circular 730. 1945.

events.title: Lehmann lovegrass introduced on Santa Rita Experimental Range.
events.description: Lehmann lovegrass introduced on Santa Rita Experimental Range.
events.source: Cable DR. Lehmann Lovegrass in the Santa Rita Experimental Range,1937-1968. Journal of Range Management. 1971;24:17-21.

events.title: Area covered (mostly) by a shallow sea.
events.description: Numerous marine invertebrates (including brachiopods, mollusks, bryozoans, corals, and echinoderms) known from area
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rocks of the Gardner Canyon Formation deposited.
events.description: Fossils include a tritylodont and a crocodilian.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: A Great Rift Valley forms in southeastern Arizona
events.description: The rift valley is associated with the formation of the Gulf of Mexico. Ocean waters fill the southeastern portion of the valley, ebbing and flowing through the years. Rift valley lakes fill the northwestern portions of the valley, as far north as Tucson. A particularly large lake, perhaps 20 miles wide and 60 miles long existed for a period in this area.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rift Valley filled with Gulf waters
events.description: Martine waters from the Fulf of Mexico fill at least portions of the rift valley in this area.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Apache Canyon Limestone Lake.
events.description: Part of the Rift valley lakes.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rift Valley fossils include sauropod, Tenontosaurus and petrified wood.
events.description: Fossils include an unnamed sauropod, Tenontosaurus and petrified wood.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rift Valley fossils include Sonorasaurus, cf. Arcrocanthosaurus and petrified wood.
events.description: Rift Valley fossils include Sonorasaurus, cf. Arcrocanthosaurus and petrified wood.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rocks of the Fort Crittenden Formation deposited
events.description: Deposited in intermontaine lakes and alluvial fans formed during early laramide deformation. Fossils include: petrified wood, pollen, snails, mussels, fishes (Lepisosteus ,Melvius, Pachyrhizodus ,Palaeolabrus), turtles (Adocus ,Plastomenus ,Helopanoplia , Trionyx sl), a polyglyphonodontine lizard, an alligatoroid and dinosaurs (Tyrannosaur, Allosauroid, Dromaeosaurid, Hadrosaurine , Nasutoceratops (?), Chasmosaur , Ankylosaurine , and Egg Shell).
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Wildfires were frequent in this area.
events.description: Demonstrating that some things never change, recent evidence suggests that wildfires were frequent in this area during this time period.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Massive volcanic activity from a giant volcano may have ended local life.
events.description: Massive volcanic activity from giant volcanos in the area, at a scale that one must suspect that life was largely eliminated. Upon empting out its magma chamber, one of the volcanos collapsed in on itself forming a giant caldera in the Mt Fagan area.
events.source: McCord R.  Timeline for Cienega Watershed. Personal Communication. May 6, 2015.

events.title: Human remains were found along Cienega Creek.
events.description: Bryon Cummings, director of the Arizona State Museum excavated two burials exposed by erosion along Cienega Creek, 3.75 meters below the modern ground surface. Based on this depth, Bryon assigned an ancient date.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Cienega Vally systematically surveyed for prehistoric sites.
events.description: Earl Swanson University of Arizona student, undertook the first systematic survey of the valley for his Master's thesis. He discovered many ceramic and preceramic period sites.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Stratigraphy and archaeological sites surveyed along Cienega Creek and Matty Canyon.
events.description: Frank Eddy, U of Arizona student, recorded the alluvial stratigraphy and ceramic and preceramic sites along Matty Canyon and Cienega Creek. Eddy applied a unique interdisciplinary approach to archaeological research. He collaborated with a geologist, palynologist and malcologist. Eddy's work demonstrated the rich cultural history spanned more than 3,000 years and that spatial pattern ing of sites could be tied to changes in the floodplain environment.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2. #Eddy FW, Cooley ME, Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona, Tucson, A: University of Arizona Press. 1983. Antropological Papers No. 43.

events.title: In Matty Canyon, excavation of a San Pedro stage preceramic site.
events.description: Frank Eddy excavated preceramic site AZ EE:2:30 buried over 5 meters in the alluvium but exposed on the channel floor of Matty Wash. Rich in remains, Eddy termed this a San Pedro phase, Cochise cultural base camp.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Evidence of early maize agriculture discovered.
events.description: In Cienega Creek alluvial sediments dated stratigraphically to the same period as EE:2:30, Paul Martin and James Schoenwetter discovered pollen evidence of early mazie agriculture.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Discoveries of deeply buried archaeological remains.
events.description: E Thomas Hemmings, M.D., Robinson and R.N. Rogers recovered burials exposed in a vertical face below over 5 meters of alluviam. Site EE:2:50.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Survey and excavations for proposed Anamax Coronado Nat'l Forest land exchange.
events.description: Arizona State Museum conducted a largescale intensive suvey and excavation project to the proposed land exchange between the Coronado National Forest and the Anamax Mining Corporation. Numerous Archaic, Hohokam, and historic sites near Rosemont were identified and excavated greatly expanding archaeologists understanding of the area.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Excavations at EE:2:30 and Los Ojitos defined Early Agricultural period.
events.description: Bruce Huckell, supported by Anamax and U of Arizona, excavated again at EE:2:30 and at Los Ojitos, 500 meters downstream in Cienega Creek channel. Large numbers of artifacts and pithouses represented early agricultural village settlement occupied year round for pershaps a decade. Work provided basis for defining the Cienega phase of Early Agricultural Period as 800 BC to AD50. Huckell notes the diverse biotic communities, first-class farmland along a gentle flowing perennial stream and a relatively long growing season were highly conducive to maize agriculture in the area.
events.source: Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Anamax archaeological surveys recorded 85 historic sites including old and new Rosemont.
events.description: To support the Anamax-Rosemont land exchange proposal, 30 square miles were surveyed on Forest Service lands and associated Anamax patented or fee lands between 1975 and 1982.
events.source: Ayres J. Rosemont: The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum. 1984 Archaeological Series 147(3).

events.title: Arizona State Museum recovered data and materials at 30 historic sites in Anamax area.
events.description: 30 sites were subjected to data recovery from the original surveys for the land exchange: 14 mining, 5 ranching, 2 schools, 2 Forest Service, and 7 misc sites. Occupation period from 1893 to about 1966 when the FS bulldozed the area to discourage hippie encampments.
events.source: Ayres J. Rosemont: The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum. 1984 Archaeological Series 147(3). http://www.rosemonteis.us/final-eis/references

events.title: Cultural resources survey at Las Ciengas revealed historic and prehistoric sites.
events.description: Harris Environmental Group conducted a cultural rsources survey for BLM, surveyed 2,214 acres. Harris identified 18 archaeological sites, including historial and prehistoric properties (mostly preceramic). Work to support BLM's grassland restoration project.
events.source: Harris Environmental Group. Cultural Resource Survey, Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. http://www.heg-inc.com/2011/03/cultural-resources-survey-las-cienegas-national-conservation-area/

events.title: Archaeological Testing at the Hummel Property prehistoric component.
events.description: SWCA completed archaeological testing along a proposed waterline within EE:2:314 (ASM) to mitigate impacts. Artifacts and analysis indicated the site used as a limited-activity locus possibly associated with Hohokam.
events.source: Ezzo JA. Archaeological Testing of a Portion of a 23-Meter-Long Segment of Waterline at AZ EE:2:3:314 (ASM), Hummel Ranch Property, Pima County, Arizona. Tucson: SWCA Environmental Consultants. 2006.

events.title: Marsh Station Road site excavations reveal early agricultural practices along Cienega Creek.
events.description: William Self Associates conducted surveys and excavations to support Kinder Morgan's new pipeline from El Paso to Phoenix. WSA partially excavated Marsh Station Rd site, a village with evidence of early agriculture in Cienega Creek. Maize cobs dated to 900 BC and 790 BC. Rich site yield pithouses, 148 features and 40,000 artifacts.
events.source: William Self Associates, Inc. A Modern Pipeline and An Ancient Place. http://www.williamself.com/Kinder%20Morgan%20-%20EPX%20Cienega%20Creek.pdf

events.title: Santa Rita Mountains (143,645 acres) nominated as a traditional cultural property
events.description: Nomination of Ce:wi Duag ("Long Mountain") as a Tohono O'odham Traditional Cultural Property. Nomination notes that others (all O'Odham, Apache, Zuni, Hopi, Pascua Yaqui along with Hispanic communities, local ranchers and residents) have deep ties and values for the Santa Rita mountains. Evidence includes historic and current uses for economic and religious uses and 7,000 years of archaeological remains.
events.source: Griset S, W Gillesie, M Farrell. National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Ce:wi Duag ("Long Mountain" in O'odham). Tucson, AZ: SWCA Environmental Consultants, U.S. Forest Service, and Trans-Sierran Archaeological Research. December 10, 2012

events.title: Sobaipuri [O'odham] occupied and utilized the Santa Ritas and watershed
events.description: Researchers have investigated protohistoric sites dating to mid-1700s (likely Sobaipuri (but possisbly Apache or Tohono O'odham) a roasting pit, house rings of stone. Reported by Kino and Manje occupied Santa Cruz and San Pedro river valleys, maintained agricultural-based villages.
events.source: Huckell, B.B. Sobaipuri Sites in the Rosemont Area. In Miscellaneous Archaeological Studies in the ANAMAX-Rosemont Land Exchange Area, edited by M.D. Tagg, R.G. Ervin, and B.B. Huckell, pp. 107–130. Archaeological Series No. 147, Vol. 4. Tucson, Arizona: Cultural Resource Management Division, Arizona State Museum, University of Arizona.

events.title: The Sobaipuri moved to Tucson after 1776
events.description: Decimated by Apache raids and disease, eventually moved to Tucson after 1776 and became absorbed into O'odham groups
events.source: Statistical Research Inc. The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present, In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources, Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan, May 2000

events.title: The Apache utilize area at least marginally
events.description: Apache were reported to be widespread in Southern Arizona but no specific remains are attributed to their camps in the Cienega Watershed.
events.source: Bronitsky G, Merritt JD. The Archaeology of Southeast Arizona: A Class I Cultural Resources Inventory. Phoenix, AZ: Bureau of Land Management. 1986. Cultural Resource Series Monograph No. 2.
